 My only point was that you CAN'T find a correlation between socialized healthcare and better healthcare. The reasons for US' high infant mortality are many. Crack babies, high illegitimacy rates, teenage pregnancies, etc., all contribute to the high infant mortality rate.

 Red herring/ IIRC, it's illegal to go outside of the system in Canada to get private treatment. In other countries, the use of private medicine is allowed, but sets up an interesting dichotomy. My guess is that the rich truly get better healthcare than the rest of the population which ISN'T the case here in the US. Here, you really can't buy better care. The average middle class patient gets the same level of care as the rich patient.
 There's lots of misconceptions about the lack of coverage for poor Americans, but it is against the law to deny emergency or life-threatening treatment for ANYBODY in the US and the level of treatment that they get is equivalent to everyone else's. 
 Where the poor in the US lack healthcare is primarily in the area of preventative healthcare and even in those cases, it is available via free clinics, etc.,
 The US pays 2-3X as much per citizen on healthcare than other OECD members. The OECD average was $ 1783, while the US average was $4178.
 In responsiveness, US was rated #1 in the world. The problem with surveys used to evaluate countries healthcare is that they don't measure quality of care, they rely more heavily on quantity of care. The US gets slammed not for the quality of care, but for the fact that 15% of Americans don't have healthcare insurance. Of course, the threee states with the largest number of uninsured people are Arizona, Texas and New Mexico. The fact that they are all border states populated with the largest number of legal and illegal immigrants from Mexico is lost in the statistics. 
 I would venture a guess that any measure of the quality of healthcare in the US far exceeds the rest of the world. Most new drugs, surgical techniques, instrumentation, protocols, etc., originate in the US. That isn't by coincidence. Capitalism promotes competition and competition promotes excellence.

 Let me go anecdotal for a moment. Eighteen months ago I suffered a severe retinal detachment in my left eye. The A&E department of my local hospital referred me to Moorfields Eye Hospital in London - a world-class ophthalmology centre. For those interested in such things, the high rate of US infant mortality is primarily caused by lack of prenatal care attributable to no health insurance. 
 
 ~Low birthweight is the primary risk factor for infant mortality and most of the decline in neonatal mortality (deaths of infants less than 28 days old) in the United States since 1970 can be attributed to increased rates of survival among low-birthweight newborns. Indeed, comparisons with countries for which data are available suggest that low birthweight newborns have better chances of survival in the United States than elsewhere. The U.S. infant mortality problem arises primarily because of its birthweight distribution; relatively more infants are born at low birthweight in the United States than in most other industrialized countries. Unfortunately, little progress has been made in reducing U.S. low birthweight rates, which would further improve infant mortality rates. 
 
 Federal and state initiatives to lower infant mortality rates have focused on strategies to reduce financial barriers that limit access to prenatal care and on strategies to expand the supply of prenatal care services available to poor pregnant women. The relative advantages and disadvantages of these and other policies to reduce low birthweight and infant mortality are the focus of considerable debate. Recent expansions of the Medicaid program are enabling more low-income children and pregnant women to obtain the health care that they need. Being eligible for Medicaid does not necessarily guarantee access to care, however, especially in areas where providers are in short supply. Hence, federal programs that provide direct support for maternal and child health services and primary care for low-income populations are also important. Some policy researchers believe, moreover, that the scope of strategies to reduce infant mortality should be broadened from a relatively narrow focus on pregnancy care to the more general issue of how to improve the health status of poor women and their families.~
 
 http://www.cbo.gov/showdoc.cfm?index=6219&sequence=0
 
 It might be noted that the US also presents the highest disparity of wages in the developed world, a contribution to the foregoing conclusion, with 12.7% below the poverty level. If one believes in statistical coincidences, rare, the 15% of Americans without health insurance is very close to that 12.7% below the poverty level. 
 
 When it comes down to US health care, it's definitely a case of you get what you can pay for.

 Aside from the mind-boggling prescription bill used to buy senior votes, increases in social spending have increased only at normal COLA rates over the past five years until 2006, when the first of annual $50-billion social spending reductions transpires (passed last week) to help pay for our expanded military budget. Inner-cities are going to become very interesting in terms of social unrest as those cuts become effective.

 
 I chose 2001 as the start because that was the last Clinton influenced budget
 P50 - 51 of the above reference:
 
 Human Resources 2001 ; 2008(est)
 Education, training, employment, social services $57.1B; $89.4B
 Health $172B; $335B
 Medicare $217 ; $349B
 Income security $$270B ; $369B
 Veterans benefits & services $45B ; $71B

For those interested in such things, the high rate of US infant mortality is primarily caused by lack of prenatal care attributable to no health insurance. 
 
 ~Low birthweight is the primary risk factor for infant mortality and most of the decline in neonatal mortality (deaths of infants less than 28 days old) in the United States since 1970 can be attributed to increased rates of survival among low-birthweight newborns. Indeed, comparisons with countries for which data are available suggest that low birthweight newborns have better chances of survival in the United States than elsewhere. The U.S. infant mortality problem arises primarily because of its birthweight distribution; relatively more infants are born at low birthweight in the United States than in most other industrialized countries. Unfortunately, little progress has been made in reducing U.S. low birthweight rates, which would further improve infant mortality rates. 
 
 Federal and state initiatives to lower infant mortality rates have focused on strategies to reduce financial barriers that limit access to prenatal care and on strategies to expand the supply of prenatal care services available to poor pregnant women. The relative advantages and disadvantages of these and other policies to reduce low birthweight and infant mortality are the focus of considerable debate. Recent expansions of the Medicaid program are enabling more low-income children and pregnant women to obtain the health care that they need. Being eligible for Medicaid does not necessarily guarantee access to care, however, especially in areas where providers are in short supply. Hence, federal programs that provide direct support for maternal and child health services and primary care for low-income populations are also important. Some policy researchers believe, moreover, that the scope of strategies to reduce infant mortality should be broadened from a relatively narrow focus on pregnancy care to the more general issue of how to improve the health status of poor women and their families.~
 
 http://www.cbo.gov/showdoc.cfm?index=6219&sequence=0
 
 It might be noted that the US also presents the highest disparity of wages in the developed world, a contribution to the foregoing conclusion, with 12.7% below the poverty level. If one believes in statistical coincidences, rare, the 15% of Americans without health insurance is very close to that 12.7% below the poverty level. 
 
 When it comes down to US health care, it's definitely a case of you get what you can pay for.
Georged, I note that no one has been able to refute this.

I don't know what would generate such personal venom in a response to known statistics about poor quality and distribution of US health care, but infant mortality is the global gauge for a nation's quality of health care and that is directly related to our disparity in income and health insurance. We in the US spend far more on prolonging the last years of life for the elderly through government funding than any other single health issue. And that will escalate beyond imagination as baby boomers line up for that freebie. 
 
 Smart people with money now fly to Thailand and India for superior, low-cost private health care for serious matters, not the US. Unless, of course, they're ousted dictators who require extreme security precautions.

 The COLA average from 2000 - 2004 was ~2.5%. If you apply that over 7 years (2008 - 2001), you get an increase of ~19% (if I did the math correctly). 
 
 Human Resources 2001 ; 2008(est)
 Education, training, employment, social services $57.1B; $89.4B 56.6% Increase
 Health $172B; $335B 94.8% increase
 Medicare $217 ; $349B 60.8% increase
 Income security $$270B ; $369B 36.7% increase
 Veterans benefits & services $45B ; $71B 57.8% increase
 
 All of those significantly surpass the average COLAs for the past 4 years. Now, I agree that the Medicare and probably a significant portion of the "Health" category are due to demographics, but Income security and Education, etc., shouldn't be. Correct?

 I haven't done the math, compounded annually, but when taking COLA, population and expanded usage due to our shift from industrial to service economy into consideration, I'd think 8-10% would be about right. I don't have access to program growth percentages, so that's a guess on my part. But I don't remember legislation expanding any programs but education and medicare (prescriptions). Both NCLB and prescription drugs, for all practical purposes, remain unfunded. If it was a business plan, I'd use 15% based solely on the continuing change to a pure two-tier system, with wealth moving upward and general wages at the bottom stagnating, forcing expansion of existing social programs.

 Quite the contrast WRT Russia. (Pretty close on France, though) emoticon_xgood Russia's contribution to the defeat of Hitler was tremendous as it should have been since it was in their national best interests to repel Germany from its soil. Most of Russia's losses in WWII occurred on Russian soil, defending the Motherland. There were no altruistic intentions in Russia's involvement; it was a purely motivated by survival. Hitler hated Communism and the Slavs. Defeating Russia would have given Hitler his needed resources AND wiped out his philosophical enemies. (If it wasn't for Hitler seeing a weakness in the Russian army when they were stalled in Finland by their own ineptitude, Hitler may have never even looked towards a conquest of Russia in the first place.) 
 Hitler didn't want US involvement in WWII. That's why he attempted to strike a deathblow to Russia quickly. Operation Barbarosa was designed as a quick kill, not as a protracted engagement. But, again..this belongs in another thread.

 The following is totally off-topic, but I'll chance it nevertheless. I consider John Hanks to be a dear friend and I respect his opinions. We go quite aways back.
 
 The UK is delightful, and London is a fabulous city. In terms of culture, heritage, and attractions, I'd rate London way above any city in America, although SF or NYC might be a close second. One of the joys of London is that you are presented with a wide choice of cuisine: Indian, Chinese (several variants), French, Italian, Middle Eastern, etc. There is a reason for this, and the reason becomes obvious when you sample the local menu. Anything beyond fish and chips, and you're forced to go the international route. I must say, though, British breakfast is exceptional: choice of eggs, sausage, ham, a unique bacon, and muffins/scones.

 It's just that at those famous name-brand dining establishments they use a small spoon to arrange a score of peas artistically next to a medalion of beef on a small plate as opposed to momma using a ladle for the peas and leavin' a lot of juice around a big fat sirloin that's hangin' off one end of my own personal platter.

 To be honest, orion has it exactly right: the British contribution to fine foods has been to cultivate and encourage the cuisine of other nations. This evening I cooked a chili con carne that I still feel proud of; last night number one son cooked a Chinese dish, and the night before we ate out at the local Portuguese restaurant. Tuesday night number two son cooked fajitas. Do you know that the UK's national dish right now, by popular acclaim, is chicken tikka masala? (Not, admittedly, a dish that ever existed in India.)
 
 Can you spell multicultural? 'Cos we sure can; and it tastes delicious.

 Depends. Judging by the selection in what that industry calls 'casual dining restaurants', meat & potatoes generally fried are still the most common fare of the US masses along with pizza, limited salad and fried chicken offerings. Our county's weight problem is a testimony to that. 
 
 I live near a couple of small towns which fortunately have a variety of fine restaurants and hole-in-the-wall ethnic specialty places due to an influx of retirees with coin and some local wealth. But one doesn't see many local working people in those places, they're lined up at the chain joints for their fine dining. I still find it difficult to understand why people pay $20+ for a cooked piece of meat that costs me $10-12 and a little fuel to cook exactly as I want it done. I'd rather spend that money on a meal out that saves hours in the kitchen.

jim's trucking

That's for sure. There are Greek, Italian, Chinese, Thai, Mediterranian, and a half dozen fast food joints within a mile from my house.

 I speak of one-of -a-kind ethnic restuarants run by families of the same ethnicity as the food. There's a small Thai restuarant downtown, the southern Bar BQ all over, the Chinese place where you can order duck feet and get them, the Cuban family-run cafe that makes the best Cuban sandwich in the world, the New York Italian brothers that put out the best quick pizza I've eaten anywhere, that oyster shack on the coast that serves half-shells by the ton and thousands of other places I've eaten some how do not compare with a home cooked, home served ethnic meal. Except for some absolutely inedible animal parts, I've sampled all the ethnic food ever put before me. In my humble opinion, the Cajun, the Mexican and the Old South Black quisine are all miles ahead of others in overall appeal.
